en_first_half: “You're a hopeless romantic,” said Faber. “It would be funny if it were not serious. It's not books you need, it's some of the things that once were in books. The same things could be in the `parlour families' today. The same infinite detail and awareness could be projected through the radios and televisors, but are not. No, no, it's not books at all you're looking for! Take it where you can find it, in old phonograph records, old motion pictures, and in old friends; look for it

The magic is only in what books say, how they stitched the patches of the universe together into one garment for us. Of course you couldn't know this, of course you still can't understand what I mean when I say all this. You are intuitively right, that's what counts. Three things are missing.
en_results_raw: in the lines on people's faces, in the way they walk, in the way the sunlight catches their hair. It's the little things, the things that make life worth living, that you're searching for. Not just the grand ideas and philosophies, but the small, quiet moments that make us human.  You're not just looking for knowledge or information; you're looking for connection, for meaning, for a sense of belonging to something bigger than yourself. You're looking for the beauty in the mundane, the magic in the everyday. And that's what's missing from the world today, that's what's been lost in the sea of technology and progress. We've forgotten how to appreciate the little things, how to slow down and truly experience life.  Faber's words struck a chord deep within Montag, resonating with a truth he had been trying to ignore. He thought about all the times he had walked by the park and never stopped to smell the flowers, all the times he had rushed past the bakery without taking a moment to appreciate the sweet aroma. He thought about all the people he had met, all the faces he had seen, and how he had never really looked at any of them, never really seen them. And he knew that Faber was right, he wasn't looking for books, he was looking for life itself.

Busque en las historias de sus abuelos, en las canciones de sus madres, en los cuentos de hadas que se narraban alrededor del fuego. Busque en la naturaleza, en el canto de los pájaros, en el susurro del viento, en la belleza de un amanecer. Busque en la pasión de los artistas, en la creatividad de los músicos, en la poesía de los escritores. Busque en la sonrisa de un niño, en la risa de un amigo, en el abrazo de un ser querido. Busque en la vida misma, en su complejidad y su simplicidad, en su belleza y su fealdad. Porque allí, y solo allí, podrá encontrar lo que busca. Allí podrá encontrar la esencia de la vida, la esencia de la humanidad, la esencia del amor. Y cuando lo encuentre, no lo olvide, no lo pierda, no lo deje escapar. Átelo a su corazón, llévelo consigo, y nunca lo suelte. Porque eso es lo que hace que la vida valga la pena, eso es lo que hace que el amor sea eterno.

And let's not forget the benefits for the baby, a natural birth can be a much gentler and more peaceful way for them to enter the world. Of course, every woman's experience is different, and what's right for one person may not be right for another. But I do think that we should be careful not to dismiss the value of a natural birth, and the potential benefits it can bring to both mother and child.

tr_results_raw: Hızla yaklaşan böceğin sesi, havayı titreten bir uğultuya dönüştü. Saniyeler içinde, böcek gözden kayboldu ve sonra, aniden, bir çakıl taşı gibi sert bir yüzeye çarptı. Çarpma sesi, bir taşın suya düşmesiyle oluşan sesi andırıyordu. Böcek, bir an için hareketsiz kaldı, sonra yavaş yavaş ayağa kalkmaya başladı. Hareketleri yavaş ve zorlu görünüyordu, sanki bir ağırlık tarafından eziliyormuş gibi. Böcek, yavaş yavaş ilerlemeye devam etti, sanki bir amacına doğru ilerliyormuş gibi.

en_first_half: He began to shuffle idiotically and talk to himself and then he broke and just ran. He put out his legs as far as they would go and down and then far out again and down and back and out and down and back. God ! God! He dropped a book, broke pace, almost turned, changed his mind, plunged on, yelling in concrete emptiness, the beetle scuttling after its running
en_second_half: food, two hundred, one hundred feet away, ninety, eighty, seventy, Montag gasping, flailing his hands, legs up down out, up down out, closer, closer, hooting, calling, his eyes burnt white now as his head jerked about to confront the flashing glare, now the beetle was swallowed in its own light, now it was nothing but a torch hurtling upon him; all sound, all blare. Now-almost on top of him !
en_results_raw: master. The sound of his footsteps echoed off the cold, grey walls as he sprinted down the desolate street, his breath coming in ragged gasps. He didn't dare look back, fearing what he might see. The beetle, its shiny black carapace glinting in the faint light, scurried after him, its tiny legs moving with an unnatural speed. The man's mind was a jumble of fear and confusion, his thoughts tumbling over each other in a chaotic mess. He had been running for what felt like hours, but he knew it was only minutes. The city seemed to stretch on forever, a endless labyrinth of concrete and steel. He darted down a side alley, hoping to lose the beetle in the narrow passageway. But it followed, its clicking growing louder, more insistent. The man's heart was racing now, his legs pumping furiously as he ran for his life. He burst out of the alley and into the bright lights of the city, the sounds of the street assaulting him like a physical blow. He weaved through the crowds, desperate to lose himself in the sea of faces. But the beetle kept coming, its relentless pursuit driving the man to the edge of madness. He stumbled, his foot catching on a loose paving stone, and almost fell. But he caught himself, his hands grasping for a nearby lamppost. He spun around, his eyes scanning the crowd frantically. And then he saw it, the beetle perched on the shoulder of a passerby, its beady eyes glinting with an evil intelligence. The man's scream was lost in the din of the city, but the beetle heard it, and it knew it was closing in.

es_first_half: Empezó a arrastrar estúpidamente los pies, a hablar consigo mismo. Y, de repente, dio un respingo y echó a correr. Alargó las piernas tanto como pudo, una y otra vez, una y otra vez. ¡Dios, Dios! Dejó caer un libro, interrumpió la carrera, casi se volvió, cambió de idea, siguió adelante, chillando en el vacío de cemento, en tanto que el vehículo parecía correr tras sus pasos, a sesenta metros
es_second_half: de distancia, a treinta, a veinticinco, a veinte; y Montag jadeaba, agitaba las manos, movía las piernas, arriba y abajo, más cerca, sudoroso, gritando con los ojos ardientes y la cabeza vuelta para enfrentarse con el resplandor de los faros. Luego, el vehículo fue tragado por su propia luz, no fue más que una antorcha que se precipitaba sobre él; todo estrépito y resplandor ¡De pronto, casi se les echó encima!
es_results_raw: de distancia. El ruido de sus pasos resonaba en el silencio de la noche, y el eco de sus gritos se perdía en la oscuridad. De repente, el vehículo se detuvo a su lado, y una puerta se abrió con un chirrido. Un hombre alto y delgado se bajó del asiento del conductor, con una mirada intensa en sus ojos. "¿Qué pasa, muchacho?", preguntó con una voz grave. El joven se detuvo en seco, jadeando, y miró al hombre con una mezcla de miedo y confusión. "¿Qué... qué pasa?", repitió, como si no entendiera la pregunta. El hombre se acercó a él, con pasos lentos y deliberados. "¿Por qué corres de esa manera?", insistió. El joven miró a su alrededor, como si buscara una escapatoria, pero el hombre lo rodeó, bloqueando su camino. "No... no sé", balbuceó, mientras el hombre lo agarraba del brazo con una mano firme. "Vamos a hablar de esto", dijo, y lo arrastró de vuelta al vehículo.

en_first_half: But the falling made a difference. An instant before reaching him the wild beetle cut and swerved out. It was
en_second_half: gone. Montag lay flat, his head down. Wisps of laughter trailed back to him with the blue exhaust from the beetle.
en_results_raw: headed straight for the nearby underbrush, its shiny black carapace glinting in the sunlight as it vanished into the dense foliage. The sudden movement had startled the air, leaving behind a faint hum that slowly dissipated into the stillness. The man stood there, frozen in surprise, his eyes fixed on the spot where the beetle had disappeared. He felt a shiver run down his spine as he realized how close the insect had come to colliding with him. The encounter left him with a sense of unease, as if the beetle's erratic flight had been a warning or an omen. He took a deep breath, trying to shake off the feeling, and continued on his way, his senses heightened as he navigated the dense undergrowth.

es_first_half: Pero la caída le salvó. Un instante antes de alcanzarle, el raudo vehículo se desvió. Desapareció. Montag yacía de bruces, con
es_second_half: la cabeza gacha. Hasta él llegó el eco de unas carcajadas, al mismo tiempo que el sonido del escape del vehículo.
es_results_raw: la cara contra el suelo, sintiendo el calor de la pista de aterrizaje y el rugido de los motores que se alejaban. Se levantó lentamente, sacudiéndose el polvo y mirando a su alrededor con una mezcla de confusión y alivio. La ciudad parecía vacía y silenciosa, como si el incidente hubiera sido solo un sueño. Pero sabía que no lo era. Sabía que había estado a punto de morir. Y sabía que tenía que seguir adelante, encontrar un lugar seguro donde esconderse y reflexionar sobre lo que había sucedido. Comenzó a caminar, sin rumbo fijo, dejándose llevar por sus pensamientos y su instinto de supervivencia.

en_first_half: They would have killed me, thought Montag, swaying, the air still torn and stirring about him in
en_second_half: dust, touching his bruised cheek. For no reason at all in the world they would have killed me.
en_results_raw: the aftermath of the explosion. He stumbled forward, his eyes scanning the desolate landscape before him. The once-familiar streets were now a twisted, smoldering ruin, the buildings reduced to rubble and ash. The silence was oppressive, punctuated only by the distant hum of sirens and the soft crackle of flames. Montag's mind reeled as he struggled to comprehend the magnitude of what had happened. The world he knew was gone, destroyed in an instant by the very people he had once trusted. He thought of Mildred, of Faber, of the countless others who had been caught in the crossfire. Were they still alive? The not knowing was almost too much to bear. With a heavy heart, Montag set off into the unknown, driven by a desperate hope of finding some semblance of humanity in this bleak, post-apocalyptic world.

Anh nhìn xung quanh, cố gắng tìm kiếm một manh mối nào đó, nhưng mọi thứ dường như quá xa vời. Đột nhiên, anh nhớ lại cuốn sách mà anh đã tìm thấy, cuốn sách mà anh đã giấu trong túi áo. Montag se sintió mareado y se agarró a la barandilla de la escalera para no caer. ¿Cómo había llegado a esto? ¿Cómo había pasado de ser un bombero que quemaba libros a ser un fugitivo que huía de la ley? La memoria de su esposa, Mildred, y su sonrisa vacía y superficial, se cruzó por su mente, y se preguntó si ella también estaría en peligro. El mundo parecía haberse vuelto del revés, y Montag no sabía cómo enderezarlo.

La oscuridad parecía cerrarse sobre él como una trampa, y Granger se sintió atrapado en una pesadilla de la que no podía despertar. Sus pensamientos eran un torbellino de confusión y miedo, y su corazón latía con una desesperación creciente. De repente, se detuvo en seco, como si hubiera escuchado algo, pero el silencio era total. Entonces, con un susurro, se preguntó a sí mismo: "¿Qué ha pasado? ¿Qué ha pasado aquí?"

en_first_half: “Now, let's get on upstream,” said Granger. “And hold on to one thought: You're not important. You're not anything. Some day the load we're carrying with us may help someone. But even when we had the books on hand, a long time ago, we didn't use what we got out of them. We went right on insulting the dead. We went right on spitting in the graves of all the poor ones who died before us. We're going to meet a lot of lonely people in the next week
en_second_half: and the next month and the next year. And when they ask us what we're doing, you can say, We're remembering. That's where we'll win out in the long run. And some day we'll remember so much that we'll build the biggest goddam steam-shovel in history and dig the biggest grave of all time and shove war in and cover it up. Come on now, we're going to go build a mirror-factory first and put out nothing but mirrors for the next year and take a long look in them.”
en_results_raw: and we're going to have to be very kind to them. What's important is that we have each other, and that we have this...this thing, this knowledge that we're carrying with us. It's a heavy burden, but it's also a privilege. We have to be careful with it, and make sure that we use it to help those who need it most. We can't let it consume us, or make us think that we're better than others. We have to stay humble, and remember that we're just messengers, carrying a message that could change the course of history.  As we walk, the landscape around us is changing. The trees are becoming more sparse, and the air is growing thick with an eerie, unnatural silence. I can feel the weight of the world's ignorance bearing down on me, and it's a crushing feeling. But I know that I'm not alone. I have Granger, and the others, and together we can face whatever lies ahead.  We're not just fighting for our own survival, or for the survival of our group. We're fighting for the future of humanity. We're fighting to preserve the knowledge that will allow our species to rebuild and start anew. It's a daunting task, but I know that we're up to it. We have to be. The alternative is unthinkable.  As the sun begins to set, casting a golden glow over the desolate landscape, I feel a sense of determination rising up within me. We're going to make it through this, I tell myself. We're going to find a way to overcome the obstacles in our path, and to bring light and knowledge back to a world that desperately needs it. And when we do, we'll be the ones who are remembered as heroes, not the ones who are forgotten in the annals of time.
vi_first_half: "Giờ ta đi ngược dòng,” Granger nói. "Và đừng bao giờ buông lơi ý nghĩ này: Các bạn không hề quan trọng. Các bạn chẳng là gì hết. Một ngày nào đó gánh nặng ta mang theo mình có thể giúp cho ai đó. Nhưng ngay cả hồi còn có sách trong tay, đã lâu rồi, chúng ta cũng đâu có dùng những gì thu được từ sách. Chứng ta cứ vậy mà sỉ nhục người đã chết. Chúng ta cứ vậy mà nhổ lên nấm mồ tất cả những người đáng thương chết trước chúng ta. Tuần sau tháng sau năm sau chúng ta sẽ gặp nhiều
vi_second_half: người cô độc. Và khi họ hỏi chúng ta đang làm gì, các bạn có thể nói: Chúng tôi đang ghi nhớ. Ấy là chỗ mà về lâu dài chúng ta sẽ thắng. Và một ngày nào đó chứng ta sẽ nhớ nhiều đến nỗi chúng ta sẽ làm ra cái máy xúc chạy hơi nước to nhất trong lịch sử, đào nấm mồ to nhất mọi thời đại, hất chiến tranh vào đó rồi lấp lại. Nào, trước hết chúng ta sẽ xây một nhà máy gương để trong năm sau sẽ sản xuất ra không gì khác ngoài những tấm gương và nhìn thật lâu vào đó."
vi_results_raw: thử thách mới, và rồi chúng ta sẽ quên mất những gì chúng ta đã học được. Chúng ta sẽ quên mất những gì chúng ta đã đọc, những gì chúng ta đã nghe, và những gì chúng ta đã thấy. Chúng ta sẽ quên mất những người đã giúp chúng ta, những người đã dạy chúng ta, và những người đã yêu thương chúng ta.  Nhưng có một điều mà chúng ta không bao giờ được quên: đó là chúng ta không hề quan trọng. Chúng ta chỉ là một phần nhỏ bé trong vũ trụ rộng lớn này. Chúng ta chỉ là một giọt nước trong đại dương bao la. Và nếu chúng ta không nhận ra điều đó, chúng ta sẽ mãi mãi là những người tự phụ, tự kiêu, và tự cao.  Chúng ta cần phải học cách khiêm tốn, học cách lắng nghe, và học cách học hỏi. Chúng ta cần phải nhận ra rằng chúng ta không biết tất cả, và rằng chúng ta luôn có thể học hỏi từ người khác. Chúng ta cần phải mở lòng, mở trí, và mở mắt để nhìn thấy thế giới xung quanh chúng ta.  Và khi chúng ta làm được điều đó, chúng ta sẽ bắt đầu thấy được giá trị của cuộc sống. Chúng ta sẽ thấy được giá trị của những người xung quanh chúng ta, của những trải nghiệm chúng ta đã có, và của những bài học chúng ta đã học được. Chúng ta sẽ thấy được rằng cuộc sống không chỉ là về chúng ta, mà là về những người khác, về thế giới xung quanh chúng ta, và về việc chúng ta có thể làm để giúp đỡ và đóng góp cho xã hội.

Pero incluso cuando teníamos los libros en la mano, mucho tiempo atrás, no utilizamos lo que sacábamos de ellos. Proseguimos impertérritos insultando a los muertos. Proseguimos escupiendo sobre las tumbas de todos los pobres que habían muerto antes que nosotros. Durante la próxima semana, el próximo mes y el próximo año
es_second_half: vamos a conocer a mucha gente solitaria. Y cuando nos pregunten lo que hacemos, podemos decir: «Estamos recordando.» Ahí es donde venceremos a la larga. Y, algún día, recordaremos tanto, que construiremos la mayor pala mecánica de la Historia, con la que excavaremos la sepultura mayor de todos los tiempos, donde meteremos la guerra y la enterraremos. Vamos, ahora. Ante todo, deberemos construir una fábrica de espejos, y durante el próximo año, sólo fabricaremos espejos y nos miraremos prolongadamente en ellos.
es_results_raw: nosotros seguiremos caminando, sin saber qué hay más allá del horizonte. Pero es posible que algún día, alguien encuentre lo que hemos dejado atrás y pueda aprender de nuestros errores. Tal vez puedan evitar cometer los mismos errores que nosotros. Tal vez puedan encontrar una forma de hacer las cosas de manera diferente. Pero hasta entonces, seguiremos adelante, sin saber qué nos depara el futuro. Seguiremos adelante, con la esperanza de que algún día, alguien pueda encontrar la forma de hacer que las cosas sean mejores. Y aunque no sepamos qué hay más allá del horizonte, seguiremos caminando, porque es lo único que sabemos hacer. Seguiremos caminando, porque es lo que hemos estado haciendo desde que empezamos este viaje. Y quién sabe, tal vez algún día encontremos lo que estamos buscando. Tal vez algún día encontremos la respuesta a todas nuestras preguntas. Pero hasta entonces, seguiremos adelante, sin mirar atrás, sin mirar hacia abajo, solo mirando hacia adelante, hacia el horizonte desconocido.
